chunks.original_text: ○ 大众玄门消息事，且好着心知，修真须务本，本立道无亏，不知道在本，焉得达瑶池。 故君子务本，本立而道生，欲求道玄，且固基本。 本固求真易，求真丧本难，本真俱有妙，方得到家山。 且夫无为则赖於有为，故知基本有，相则辩於无，相要识当头，识得当头破，方开耳目聪，元来真妙化，只在本身中。 须知击石有火，坑地即渊，思福当善，断因灭缘，解渴必水，敌寒则绵，进真成道，慎过无愆。 但人能精进持诵，念道思真，善功不退，行满功成，吉祥集降，神沐逍遥，永享太玄矣。 咄！ 胜景谩夸三岛有，满怀风月更翛然。 颂曰： 重楼华馆涌灵泉，中有丹皇号自然。 混有郁罗开大有，冲虚金鼎运真玄。 阳神保镇三明地，阴魄降擒六洞天。 莫向枕边迷幻梦，恐孤寒月满渔船。 即说北斗咒曰： 北斗九辰，中天大神。 上朝金阙，下覆昆仑。 调理纲纪，统制乾坤。 大魁贪狼，巨门禄存。 文曲廉贞，武曲破军。 高上玉皇，紫微帝君。 大周天界，细入微尘。 何灾不灭，何福不臻。 元皇正炁，来合我身。 天罡所指，昼夜常轮。 俗居小人，好道求灵。 愿见尊仪，永保长生。 三台虚精，六淳曲生。 生我养我，护我身形。 □□□□□□□尊帝，急急如律令敕！ 颂曰： 玄牝枢机列化神，荐登真理沐洪恩。 祥烟塞断回遑路，新月开通乐逸门。 正炁摄生安禹稷，灵源保育运昆仑。 七元不昧流光照，万圣来前卫我尊。 老君曰：凡人性命五体，悉属本命星官之所主掌，本命神将，本宿星官，常垂荫佑，主持人命，使保天年。 凡俗无知，终身不悟。 夫本命真官，每岁六度降在人间，降日为本命限期，有南陵使者三千人，北斗真君七千神将，本命真官降驾众真，悉来拥护。 且夫道育天地之根，炁补五行之用，物盗天地之灵以成茂，人盗万物之精以求安，故三才五行，人伦命物，皆非道不生，故非道不立，一切万物皆不出於大道者矣。 故以道含万汇，人悟一心，万汇播经，非出於道，一心变用，莫实於真，凡欲学道归真，修身保性者，当务於真实，故天实可运於日月，故地实可载於含灵，人实於诸世中，自然大道之真可成就无漏也。 故真心实行，道则无虚以成真，若顽心不戒，圣功何以达玄门，一切行业当要实功，我玄极之大道用而有真。 奈浮世迷人，看之若假。 呜呼！ 但浅根薄行之众生，岂信玄门别有幽极之妙理，唯只乐情欲为欢，竞浮财而作富见，言邪欲争竞欲闻，闻说真空如起伟，妬谤玄门若泥沙，贪非为忘性命，玄真妙理，隔万重之烟水，苦海迷津，何时得越於道岸哉！ 以此为凡夫无知，自身不悟，故我太上启无为之金口，吐济物之玄珠，指三天之有路，塞九夜之无门，利益群生，恩沾众品，诱上善成天真，引中下归正道，教演三乘，经垂万化，盖为众生种性不同，根器各异，说上乘化上根，有中下之人，必不能达於此理，为缚心炼性，默默无言，绵绵用道，进无形之理，慕无像之真，非上根无由达理。 故说中乘下乘用外缘而引见内真，说有相而辩於无漏矣。 且如本命真官，每岁六度降在人间者，谓六十甲子所属生年之日，即为本命、每年有六次逢值，即是本命下日也。 其日有当生本宿星官、本命神将下降世间，观察善恶，兼有南陵三千使者，北斗七千神将，俱来拥护，此日即宜斋戒礼诵，忏悔祈禳，皈敬众真，钦崇本命，当得灾咎消除，命年遐永矣。
chunks.translated_text:
**On the Mysteries of the Daoist Gate for All Disciples**

All within the Daoist gate should attend carefully to these matters. Those who cultivate the Real must focus on the root, for when the root is established, the Dao remains unharmed. Without knowing the root of the Dao, how can one reach the Jasper Pool? Thus the noble person attends to the root, and when the root is established, the Dao arises. To seek the mysteries of the Dao, first secure the root. With the root firm, seeking the Real is easy; seeking the Real while losing the root is difficult. Only when both root and Real are perfected does one arrive at the homeland of the Dao.

Moreover, non-action relies upon action. Thus, knowing the root exists in the manifest, one distinguishes it from the unmanifest. To recognize the root, one must first identify its essence. Once this essence is discerned and broken through, the ears and eyes become keen. The true and wondrous transformation has always resided within one’s own body.

Know that striking stone produces fire, and digging earth creates a deep abyss. To cultivate blessings, act with goodness; to sever karmic causes, cut off conditions. To quench thirst, one must have water; to resist cold, one must have silk. To advance in the Real and attain the Dao, guard against transgressions and avoid faults.

If one can diligently recite and uphold the teachings, meditate on the Dao, and contemplate the Real—without regressing in virtuous practice—then when merit is complete and deeds fulfilled, auspicious blessings will gather and descend. The spirit will be bathed in carefree ease, and one shall forever enjoy the Great Mystery.

Ah!
Though the fair scenes of the Three Isles are much praised,
The heart filled with wind and moon is yet more serene.

**Verse:**
Lofty towers and splendid halls well forth with numinous springs,
Within dwells the Cinnabar Sovereign, named the Natural.
The Primordial Chaos unfolds into lush abundance,
The Void Cauldron of Gold revolves with true mystery.
The yang spirit guards and stabilizes the land of Three Clarities,
The yin soul subdues and captures the Six Cavern Heavens.
Do not be deluded by illusory dreams at your pillow’s edge,
Lest the cold moon fill the fisherman’s boat in solitude.

Then follows the incantation of the Northern Dipper:

Northern Dipper of the Nine Luminaries, great deities of the central heavens,
Above you ascend to the Golden Palace, below you cover Kunlun.
You regulate the cosmic order, govern the cosmos.
Great Dipper, Greedy Wolf, Gigantic Gate, Store of Emolument,
Literary Brilliance, Integrity and Chastity, Martial Brilliance, Breaker of Armies.
Supreme Jade Emperor, Purple Tenuity Emperor Lord,
Encompassing the great celestial sphere, entering even the tiniest dust.
What disaster cannot be eradicated? What blessing cannot be attained?
The primal qi of the Original Sovereign comes to merge with my body.
Wherever the Celestial Stem points, it revolves day and night without cease.
The common folk, petty and unenlightened, seek the Dao and crave numinous power.
May they behold your august presence and forever preserve long life.
The Three Terraces of Void Essence, the Six Pure Ones of Curved Birth,
Give birth to me, nurture me, protect my body and form.
[...] Venerable Emperor, swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

**Verse:**
The Mysterious Female’s pivot and mechanism array the transforming spirits,
Offering ascent to the Real and bathing in vast grace.
Auspicious mists block the path of hesitation,
The new moon opens the gate of joyous ease.
The upright qi gathers life, pacifying Yu and Ji,
The numinous source protects and nurtures, revolving Kunlun.
The Seven Primes, undimmed, radiate their luminous glow,
The myriad sages draw near to guard my honor.

Lord Laozi said: The nature, life, and five constituents of all people are entirely governed by the star officials of their original destiny. The spirit-generals of their original destiny and the star officials of their natal constellation constantly bestow their protective shade, sustaining life and preserving one’s allotted years. Yet the common folk, ignorant, pass their lives without awakening.

The true officials of one’s original destiny descend to the human realm six times each year. The day of descent is called the *limit-period of original destiny*. On that day, three thousand messengers of the Southern Mound and seven thousand spirit-generals of the Northern Dipper, along with the true officials of original destiny, descend in the company of all the perfected to surround and protect.

Moreover, the Dao nurtures the root of heaven and earth, and qi supplements the functions of the Five Phases. Things steal the numinous essence of heaven and earth to flourish, while humans steal the essence of the myriad things to seek stability. Thus the Three Powers and Five Phases, human relationships, destiny, and all things cannot be born without the Dao, nor can they stand without it. All things in the universe do not transcend the Great Dao.

Therefore, the Dao embraces the myriad phenomena. When humans awaken to the One Mind, the myriad phenomena propagate through the scriptures—yet they do not arise from outside the Dao. The One Mind transforms and operates, and nothing is more substantial than the Real. Those who wish to learn the Dao and return to the Real, to cultivate the body and preserve their nature, must attend to what is real and true.

Heaven can indeed be moved by the sun and moon, earth can indeed bear the numinous beings, and humans, among all the worlds, can naturally accomplish the true and perfect Dao, achieving the untainted.

Thus, with a true heart and sincere practice, the Dao is never empty in its realization of the Real. But if one’s heart is stubborn and unrepentant, how can sacred merit reach the gate of the Mystery? All practices must be grounded in true effort, for the great Dao of our Mystery Ultimate operates through the Real.

Alas! The floating world deludes people, who regard it as false. Alas! Shallow-rooted beings of meager practice—how could they believe the Daoist gate holds other profound and wondrous principles? They only delight in sensual pleasures, compete for fleeting wealth, and take pride in riches. They speak perversely and vie to hear contentious words. When they hear of true emptiness, they react with arrogance, slandering the Daoist gate as if it were mud and sand. They covet what is not theirs and forget their nature and life. The wondrous principles of the Mysterious Real are veiled by ten thousand layers of mist and water. In the bitter sea of delusion, when will they cross to the shore of the Dao?

Because the common people are ignorant and do not awaken to themselves, the Most High opens his golden mouth of non-action, spitting forth the mysterious pearl to aid all things. He points out the path to the Three Heavens and blocks the gateless Nine Nights. Benefiting all beings, his grace moistens all ranks. He guides the most excellent to become celestial perfected, leads the middling and lesser to return to the correct Dao, teaches the Three Vehicles, and transmits the scriptures of ten thousand transformations.

This is because the seed-nature of beings differs, and their faculties vary. To convert those of superior roots, the superior vehicle is taught. But there are those of middling and lesser capacity who cannot grasp this principle. For them, binding the heart and refining the nature, silently and wordlessly applying the Dao, advancing the formless principle, and yearning for the imageless Real—none but those of superior roots can comprehend this.

Thus the middle and lesser vehicles use external conditions to reveal the inner Real, expounding the manifest to distinguish the untainted.

As for the true officials of original destiny descending six times each year to the human realm, this refers to the days corresponding to the sixty-year cycle of one’s birth year—these are the *original destiny days*. Each year, there are six occasions when one’s original destiny aligns, which are the *descent days of original destiny*. On these days, the star officials of one’s natal constellation and the spirit-generals of one’s original destiny descend to the world to observe good and evil. Accompanied by three thousand messengers of the Southern Mound and seven thousand spirit-generals of the Northern Dipper, they all come to surround and protect.

On these days, one should practice abstinence, recite scriptures, repent, and pray for expiation. Revering the host of perfected and honoring one’s original destiny will dissolve calamities and misfortunes, extending one’s years and destiny.

chunks.original_text: 或谓南陵使者三千人者，乃离火之象，丹阳之宫三阳为三魂，动则神灵生而主於心也，心能禁制形神，使不乱也。 北斗七千神将者，坎水之形，黑阴之府，七精开七窍，通则光明彻而主於肾也，肾能慎固精气，使不坏也。 此乃人身中本真所在之处，因真元在谷，则得三尸七魄六欲九虫悉皆顺道，而有万神众真尽来拥护，此乃道之实也。 咄！ 会得太玄消息意，泰山变作玉京山。 颂曰： 爱河岸阔浪迷天，且好抽身上法船。 制得耍猿眠卉径，任教意马走芳田。 达开玄理头头道，悟到幽机处处禅。 月夜独吟高举棹，家乡掩映古峰前。 可以消灾忏罪，请福延生，随力章醮，福德增祟。 其有本命限期将至，自身不知，不设斋醮，不修香火，此为轻生迷本，不贵人身，天司夺禄，减算算除年，多致夭丧。 迷误之者，虽遇经诀，怀不信心，毁谤真文。 如此之人，身谢之后，沦没三涂，漂沉诸趣，永失人身，深可悲哀，自致斯苦。 窃惟求烟而近木，救渴而近泉，戒非而近善，恶愚而近贤。 夫木性非炎，钻之则火出，人心逐欲，戒之则道生，非贤勿辫愚，非泉勿释渴，非正勿知邪，非真勿知假，以假显真，以邪知正。 且如玉台悬宝鉴，辉辉其中，岂汝有形骸，秉大道玄玄於中何尔无，夫宝鉴本真，内现者虚假形骸，元假中隐者乃真，当以心镜拂拭绝纤尘，性合道兮周沙界，大道无物不包，含性则无心而不乱，万物已知为假，一心独照为真，若取物用之，乐道无由，若离物言之，登天没路，是乃引目海涯，忽观桂月，闲游山径，顿觉松风，因恶而可从善，为假而可知真，因凡则知圣，因苗则知根。 且以凡夫在世众生，不以假物指真，如何辩有像，不以法相传空，如何识无形，故以圣人垂化，用於未悟者也。 故太上曰：知者不言，言者不知是也。 若有我等一切几夫众生，悟斯大道，知本命限期，持此玄经进步仙阶，能精修不退者，自然福德增崇。 若不进玄功，轻生弃命之徒，当自性入别骸，心攒万若灰，河明报何时，彻铁域拘囚，甚日休争如。 好凭一智登天路，莫顺三尸作地囚。 颂曰： 随力修真则见真，苦修多作始初勤。 当须要办真实行，方入无为自在门。 业海省无千里岸，蓬山迷有万重云。 渔灯照处寒江静，鸥鹭惊飞失旧群。 若本命之日，能修斋醮，善达天司，一世於本命限期，开转真经，广陈供养，使三生常为男子身，富贵聪明，人中殊胜。 盖闻情起乎物，识起乎心，欲情起则三山作罗酆，情欲灭则九夜为玄府，大抵群魔众苦缘甚而来？ 八难十缠为何而至？ 欲物乃群魔众苦之根，乱性乃八难十缠之首，欲乃本无根，目乃欲之首，魔则本无碍，心是魔之因，故五音令人耳聋，五色令人目盲。 《阴符经》云：瞽者善听，聋者善视，绝利一源，用师十倍，三反昼夜，用师万倍是也。 盖万缘千行，皆出於一心也。 又云：柳绿桃红，乃眼前之幻化，风清月白，是劫外之生涯。 若寂照太微，则神生丹阙，如昏迷世欲，则魄坠寒池，诸尘诸漏，万种万端，只要於假内认元初这个，於无中觅实有容仪，则可以行大道也。 ○大众乃以目前境界，浩浩多端，俗态迷因，般般无尽，七情六欲，五鬼三尸，化邪欲诳尔入迷河，用俗乐唆君归业海，种种祸临，何如奈忍，但当降其心，而群魔自伏，戒其欲，而众苦消除，心灭则万法皆灭，情生则众苦自生，入道玄门，幽关夜府，路本一条，刚行两径，神灵射九夜开光，魄散昧三山闭黑，天堂之乐，地狱之囚，为非之果，作善之由，皆随灵台而变化，从智性而出现者也。
chunks.translated_text:
The three thousand messengers of the Southern Mound are likened to the image of *li* fire, the three yang of the Cinnabar Yang Palace forming the three hun-souls. When activated, the numinous spirit is born and presides over the heart. The heart can restrain the form and spirit, preventing disorder.

The seven thousand spirit-generals of the Northern Dipper take the form of *kan* water, the abode of black yin. The seven essences open the seven orifices; when unobstructed, radiance pervades and governs the kidneys. The kidneys can securely guard the essence and qi, preventing their dissipation.

These are the loci of the original true within the human body. When the true origin resides in the valley, the Three Corpses, Seven Po, Six Desires, and Nine Worms all follow the Dao, and the myriad spirits and host of perfected come to surround and protect. This is the reality of the Dao.

Ah! If one comprehends the subtle message of the Great Mystery, Mount Tai transforms into the Jade Capital Mountain.

A hymn says:
The shore of the River of Love is vast, waves delude the heavens,
Best to withdraw and board the Dharma boat.
Restrain the playful monkey to sleep on the herb-strewn path,
Let the willful horse roam the fragrant fields.
Penetrating the profound principle, the Dao is everywhere,
Awakening to the subtle mechanism, Chan is in all places.
On a moonlit night, chanting alone, hoist the oar,
The homeland shimmers before the ancient peaks.

This can dissolve calamities, repent sins, invoke blessings, and extend life. According to one’s capacity, perform rites and offerings, and merit and virtue will increase.

If the term of one’s original destiny is approaching and one remains unaware, failing to establish abstinence rites or tend incense and fire, this is to trifle with life and be deluded about one’s origin, not cherishing the human form. The celestial offices will revoke one’s emoluments, diminish one’s allotted years, and often lead to premature death.

Those who err in this way, even if they encounter scriptural instructions, harbor disbelief and slander the true texts. After such persons pass away, they sink into the Three Wretched Realms, drift through the various destinies, and forever lose the human form. Deeply pitiable, they bring this suffering upon themselves.

Just as one seeks smoke near wood or quenches thirst near a spring, one shuns wrongdoing to draw near goodness and flees folly to approach wisdom. Wood’s nature is not fiery, yet drilling it produces flame; the human heart pursues desires, yet restraint gives rise to the Dao. Without the worthy, do not debate folly; without a spring, do not slake thirst; without the upright, do not recognize the perverse; without the true, do not know the false. By the false, the true is revealed; by the perverse, the upright is known.

For instance, the Jade Terrace suspends a precious mirror, its radiance resplendent within. How can you, possessing a bodily form, hold the profound mystery of the Great Dao yet remain devoid of it? The precious mirror is the original true; what appears within it is the illusory bodily form. The true is concealed within the false. One should polish the heart-mirror to remove even the finest speck of dust. When one’s nature harmonizes with the Dao, it pervades the ten thousand realms. The Great Dao encompasses all things; when one’s nature is contained, the mind is never disordered. Once one knows the ten thousand things to be false, the solitary mind alone illumines the true. If one grasps and uses things, there is no way to delight in the Dao; if one departs from things in speech, there is no path to ascend to heaven. This is like gazing toward the sea’s edge and suddenly beholding the osmanthus moon, or strolling a mountain path and instantly sensing the pine wind. Through aversion, one may follow goodness; through the false, one may know the true. Through the ordinary, one knows the sage; through the sprout, one knows the root.

Moreover, the common people in the world, the multitude of beings, do not use false things to point to the true—how then can they discern forms? Without using dharmic appearances to transmit emptiness, how can they recognize the formless? Thus, the sages bestow transformation for the sake of the unenlightened.

Therefore, the Most High said: “Those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know.”

If all of us, the multitude of beings, awaken to this Great Dao, know the term of our original destiny, and advance along the immortal’s steps by upholding this profound scripture with unwavering dedication, our merit and virtue will naturally increase.

If one does not progress in the mysterious work but is instead one who trifles with life and abandons destiny, one’s inherent nature will enter another bodily form, the heart will gather myriad sorrows like ashes, and when will the river of karma become clear? One will be bound and imprisoned in the iron domain—how can one ever rest?

Better to rely on a single wisdom to ascend the heavenly path; do not follow the Three Corpses to become a prisoner of the earth.

A hymn says:
Practice the true according to your capacity, and you will see the true;
Arduous cultivation requires diligence from the outset.
One must undertake genuine and steadfast practice
To enter the gate of non-action and attain freedom.
The sea of karma has no thousand-mile shore,
The Penglai Mountains are obscured by ten thousand layers of clouds.
Where the fisherman’s lamp shines, the cold river is still,
Gulls and egrets take startled flight, losing their former flock.

If on the days of one’s original destiny one performs abstinence rites and communicates with the celestial offices, within the term of one’s original destiny one may open and transmit the true scripture, widely present offerings, and thereby ensure that for three lifetimes one will always be reborn as a man, wealthy, noble, intelligent, and preeminent among people.

It is said that emotions arise from things, perceptions from the mind. When desire and emotion arise, the Three Mountains become Fengdu; when desire and emotion cease, the Nine Nights become the Mysterious Mansion. Generally, why do the host of demons and myriad sufferings come? Why do the Eight Difficulties and Ten Entanglements arise? Desires are the root of the host of demons and myriad sufferings; disordered nature is the chief of the Eight Difficulties and Ten Entanglements. Desire has no root—it is the eye that leads desire; demons have no hindrance—it is the heart that gives rise to demons. Thus, the five tones deafen the ears, and the five colors blind the eyes.

The *Yin Fu Jing* states: “The blind excel in hearing, the deaf excel in seeing. Cut off the source of profit, and your forces are tenfold; reverse this three times day and night, and your forces are ten thousandfold.”

All the myriad conditions and thousand practices arise from the single heart.

It is also said: The green willows and red peaches are illusory transformations before one’s eyes; the clear wind and white moon are the livelihood beyond the kalpa. If one silently illuminates the Great Tenuity, the spirit is born in the Cinnabar Palace; if one is deluded by worldly desires, the po-soul falls into the Cold Pool. The myriad dusts and leaks, the ten thousand kinds and ends—one need only recognize the original within the false and seek the substantial appearance within the formless. Then one may practice the Great Dao.

Oh, the assembly! The present circumstances are vast and multifarious, the delusions of worldly states are endless. The seven emotions and six desires, the five ghosts and three corpses, transform into demons to deceive you into the river of delusion, using worldly pleasures to lure you into the sea of karma. All manner of calamities descend—how can one bear them? One must only subdue the heart, and the host of demons will submit; restrain desire, and the myriad sufferings will dissolve. When the heart is extinguished, the ten thousand dharmas are extinguished; when emotions arise, the myriad sufferings arise. Entering the mysterious gate of the Dao, the night palace of the hidden pass, the path is fundamentally one, yet one may walk two ways. The numinous spirit shines, opening the light of the Nine Nights; the po-soul scatters, darkening the Three Mountains. The joys of heaven, the imprisonment of hell, the fruits of wrongdoing, the causes of good acts—all transform according to the spirit-terrace and manifest from wisdom and nature.
chunks.overlap_context:
and the spirit-generals of one’s original destiny descend to the world to observe good and evil. Accompanied by three thousand messengers of the Southern Mound and seven thousand spirit-generals of the Northern Dipper, they all come to surround and protect.

On these days, one should practice abstinence, recite scriptures, repent, and pray for expiation. Revering the host of perfected and honoring one’s original destiny will dissolve calamities and misfortunes, extending one’s years and destiny.

chunks.original_text: 若有众生能知本命之理，清净斋戒，灭於尘漏，其善功超达天司，获相貌端严，位登真人，得越苦海，皆因降心伏魔，从善戒恶，可登仙界逍遥，不致幽牢拘锁。 若有持经办道之士，遵依太上之文，不犯圣真之禁，得道成仙，乃蒙恩先圣，将何以报之，故《证道歌》云：粉骨碎身未足醉，一念了然超亿劫是也。 只要慕道了然，心涤无垢，便为不负天地之理也。 咄！ 凿开石壁无遮障，万象森罗掌内观。 颂曰： 玄灵大愍济牢笼，广化三乘悟太空。 目下自知宜取用，云中他说莫寻踪。 桃汉柳岸君家事，桂月松风我祖宗。 堪笑几多学道者，却贪尘景走西东。 其有生身果薄，虽在人中，贫穷下贱，纵知本命，无力修崇，能酌水献花，冥心望北极，稽首礼拜，念本命真君名号者，亦不虚过本命限期，皆得延生注福，系系人身，灾厄蠲除，获福无量。 天师欢喜，踊跃作礼，赞叹难可得遇无上法桥。 夫水性至平，浪因风起，人心本静，动自物生。 物不着兮情不生，心常虚兮欲自灭。 爱欲起於心，形神丧於物，漫漫业海不归岸，而一任漂流，黯黯罗酆竞涉路，而从教险峻，直待失时方觉悟，日中扶影护惆忄厨。 ○大众贪爱狂迷痴悭吝，惜愚人不悟，此乃丧性命之因，迷真玄之本，俗乐贪迷非君之益，道心开发乃我之荣，云霞幽洞闲日月之光，丽阁华堂昭星霜之变，物外离尘境界别有逍遥，世间虚华俗乐岂无患害。 凡修真炼性者，当要十二时中、一百刻内，行坐施为，清净身心，常立方便，自然累功积行，善达三天，登真得道矣。 故太上有曰：进善若偷是，故於尘世之中和光顺时，随缘立善，若言善不行善，则证道无门，见非能戒非，则登真有路。 凡欲修真学仙之人，当建真实之行也。 且如世间贫贱高下，然各有等差，大道真空，则实无分别，有肃智清心而进道，有陈幡列像以祈恩，善立各门，恩成一路，世情有富贫之间，天心无高下之分，但能起一念进道为善之心，外则天真地神佑之，内则元命形神乐之，自然灾厄蠲除，获福无量。 是时天师得受是经，不胜欣喜。 天师者，秉道辅正曰天之师，迷真逐邪曰地之鬼，故悟真大道之人，正可谓得遇无上法桥矣。 咄！ 一神秉正无邪谄，三界逍遥总在渠。
chunks.translated_text:
If there are sentient beings who understand the principle of their original destiny, purify themselves through fasting and precepts, and extinguish the leaks of worldly dust, their meritorious deeds will ascend to the heavenly courts, granting them dignified and majestic countenances, attaining the rank of Perfected Ones, and crossing beyond the sea of suffering—all because they subdued the heart and overcame demons, embraced goodness and renounced evil, thus ascending to the carefree immortal realms, avoiding the shackles of dark prisons.

For those who uphold the scriptures and cultivate the Dao, following the texts of the Most High and transgressing none of the sacred prohibitions, attaining the Dao and becoming immortals, they receive the grace of the ancient sages. How shall they repay this? As the *Song of Realizing the Dao* says: "To grind one’s bones to powder is still insufficient repayment; a single thought of clarity transcends kalpas beyond count."

One must only yearn for the Dao with clarity, purifying the heart until it is free of defilement—this is to not betray the principle of heaven and earth.

Hark!
Chisel open the stone wall, and no barrier remains;
The ten thousand images and all phenomena appear within the palm.

A eulogy says:
The mysterious and numinous, in great compassion, delivers from the cage;
Broadly transforming the Three Vehicles to awaken to the Great Void.
Before your eyes, you know what to take and use—
Do not seek traces in the clouds where others speak.

The peach-laden Han and willow-lined shores are your family’s affairs;
The osmanthus moon and pine winds are the legacy of my ancestors.
How laughable are those many Dao-seekers
Who chase after worldly scenes, running east and west.

For those whose karmic endowment is meager, though born among humans, poor and lowly, even if they understand their original destiny but lack the means to cultivate, if they can pour water or offer flowers, silently turn their minds toward the Northern Culmen, bow in reverence, and invoke the name of their Original Destiny True Lord, they shall not pass their destined lifespan in vain. All will gain extended life and recorded blessings, securing human rebirth in every generation, dispelling calamities, and obtaining boundless fortune.

The Heavenly Master rejoiced, leapt with joy, and bowed in reverence, praising the rare encounter with this supreme Dharma-bridge.

Now, the nature of water is perfectly level, yet waves arise with the wind; the human heart is originally still, but movement arises from external things. When things do not cling, emotions do not arise; when the heart remains empty, desires naturally fade. Love and desire arise from the heart, while form and spirit are lost to external things. Adrift in the boundless sea of karma without returning to shore, one drifts at will; dimly traversing the paths of Fengdu, one follows perilous routes—only when the time is lost does one awaken, like propping up a shadow at noon to guard against sorrow.

O assembly! Greed, infatuation, delusion, stinginess, and miserliness—how pitiful that foolish people do not awaken! These are the causes of losing one’s nature and life, the roots of straying from the true mystery. Worldly pleasures and blind attachment bring no benefit; the opening of the Dao-heart is our true glory. Clouds and mist in secluded caves idle away the light of sun and moon; ornate pavilions and splendid halls reveal the changes of stars and frost. Beyond the world, apart from dust, there is another realm of carefree wandering—how can the fleeting vanities and worldly pleasures of the mundane realm be free from harm?

Those who cultivate truth and refine their nature must, within the twelve hours and one hundred moments of each day, in all actions whether moving or still, keep body and mind pure, always establishing expedient means. Naturally, merits and deeds will accumulate, goodness will reach the Three Heavens, and one will ascend to Perfection and attain the Dao.

Thus, the Most High has said: "Advancing goodness is like stealing." Therefore, in the dusty world, one harmonizes with light and follows the times, establishing goodness according to conditions. If one speaks of goodness but does not practice it, the gate to realizing the Dao remains closed; if one sees wrongdoing and can renounce it, the path to ascending as a Perfected One lies open.

Those who wish to cultivate truth and learn immortality must establish truthful conduct. Though in the world, poverty and nobility, high and low, each have their distinctions, the Great Dao and true emptiness are truly without differentiation. Some advance the Dao through solemn wisdom and a pure heart; some set up banners and arrange images to pray for blessings. Though the methods differ, all lead to the same path. While worldly conditions vary between wealth and poverty, the heart of heaven makes no distinction between high and low. If one can arouse a single thought of advancing the Dao and doing good, externally, the celestial and terrestrial spirits will protect them; internally, their original destiny, form, and spirit will delight. Naturally, calamities will be dispelled, and boundless fortune obtained.

At this time, the Heavenly Master received this scripture, overflowing with joy.

The Heavenly Master is one who upholds the Dao and assists rectitude—thus called the Teacher of Heaven. Those who stray from the true and pursue the perverse are called ghosts of the earth. Therefore, those who awaken to the Great Dao of truth may truly be said to have encountered the supreme Dharma-bridge.

Hark!
One spirit upholds rectitude, free of deceit;
The Three Realms’ carefree wandering all lie within.

The joys of heaven, the imprisonment of hell, the fruits of wrongdoing, the causes of good acts—all transform according to the spirit-terrace and manifest from wisdom and nature.

chunks.original_text: 颂曰： 柳岸分明横法桥，迷来恰似路迢遥。 烟飞江浦山光淡，日照幽村野色消。 幸是本来无着相，强教今日话忉忉。 不知回首人间几，月白风清我独招。 太上玄灵北斗本命延生真经注解卷中 #1『皈依』，同《经注》本，《真经注》本作『归真』。 #2『虽还明师』，当作『虽遇明师』。 #3『而矣』，疑当作『中矣』。 太上玄灵北斗本命延生真经注解卷下 崆峒山玄元真人注解并颂 老君重告天师曰：世人罪福善恶皆属天司，忏罪消灾，莫越修奉，遇本命生辰，告身中元辰驿马，削落三灾九厄，保见今眷属安宁。 原夫天地无象，道隐於混黄，日月未形，炁含於太朴，一炁足而黄中理，大朴散而物始生，三才布化於群灵，六运吹嘘於橐钥，寒暑迁变，律吕和彰，上散日月之晶，布其星辰，下凝清浊之滓，列其丘岳，产育万物，滋长群生，人盗万物致宁，物耗人兮致道，春茂则秋衰，有生而有灭，若不形而不像，亦无死以无终。 ○大众眼睫不远於目，视见弗然，大道只在於心，修之岂识，云宫梵阙，宝苑骞林，将有相而识於无相，仗化缘而知於空缘，因有为则至於无为，为有相而得於无相，灵台不昧道应明，尘积昏朦神必暗，灵竭精溃，形病身亡，三魂渺漠空於阴路，太悠悠，百节形骸谩向荒丘，寂黯黯，饶敌一国之富，此日那荣，空传六印之名，於期何济，世之迷爱欲而多失元辰，纵贪婪而广况驿马，目视桃红柳绿，不知空色之由，意随蝶舞花飞，岂别因缘之分，於海波阔远处旋涡中，宛转甚时休，在山石深厚地云穴内，乱窜何日止。 但世人恶湿而居下，畏死而贪生，不知生者死之根，过者祸之首，自当畏湿而居高，贪生而脱死，恐祸而慎过，防患而戒非，自然逍遥为陆地之仙也。 且夫众生作非犯禁，累成过咎，何法得免，何计得禳？ 在乎悔省前非，永绝后过，精思太玄，恭勤敬奉自己身中元辰驿马，可得削落三灾九厄，保见今春属安宁。 如何是告身中元辰驿马？ 盖元者始初也，辰者真象也，驿者宅谷也，马者顽兽也，欲请福，当祷祈，参求本来元初，同大道，合天地，运日月，齐山岳，通幽达玄，无为无碍，这个元辰，悔过迁善，便可消灾度厄矣。 能缚自身宅谷中意马，心猿得住，自然万灾不干，群邪稽首，则得逍遥三界，乃证玄玄者矣。 咄！ 自身驿马擒降住，方得元辰落九灾。 颂曰： 莫击元神五蕴山，就中虚幻事多难。 迷云常惹灵台伴，爱浪频潮丹阙间。 九厄渐生猿马旺，三灾转起鬼邪顽。 谁知照见真消息，风月依依两不干。 凡有上士於本命生辰持此真文者，外伏魔精，内安真性，功沾水陆，善及存亡，悔过虔恭，渐登妙果，重立玄功，证虚无道，乃得圣智圆通，隐显莫测，出有入无，逍遥云际，升入金门，与圣合真，身超三界，永不轮转，寿量无穷，快乐自在。 且夫善恶之各异，皆出自於所为，祸福之两途，乃实因於所措，大抵幻魔纵则愆必积，心业灭，则罪亦亡，虽知善恶祸福，如影逐形，莫可逃之。 且世间凡夫众生，不知何以至亲，何以至大，虽知惟道至大，惟命至亲。 今乃知道大命亲，何以求之？ 何以护之？ 须知枢之自轮，纲之自纪，一心摄正，万法无邪，亲者不能敬，焉能敬其疏，内者不能悦，焉能悦於外，则敬亲广兮疏必善之，则悦内加兮外必推之，是故可正於一身，自然弗令而顺之者也。

A Hymn says:
The willow-lined shore distinctly spans the Dharma-bridge,
Yet deluded, one finds the path as distant as can be.
Mist drifts o’er riverbanks where mountain hues grow faint,
Sunlight bathes the secluded hamlet, wild hues fade away.
Fortunate indeed—originally free from clinging forms,
Yet forced today to speak of ceaseless woe.
Who knows how many in the human realm turn back their gaze?
Moonlit and wind-clear, I alone beckon.

*Taishang Xuanling Beidou Benming Yansheng Zhenjing Zhujie*, Scroll Middle
1. "皈依" (*guīyī*)—same as in the *Jingzhu* edition; the *Zhenjing Zhu* writes "归真" (*guīzhēn*).
2. "虽还明师" (*suī huán míngshī*)—should read "虽遇明师" (*suī yù míngshī*).
3. "而矣" (*ér yǐ*)—likely should read "中矣" (*zhōng yǐ*).

*Taishang Xuanling Beidou Benming Yansheng Zhenjing Zhujie*, Scroll Lower
Commentary and Hymns by Xuanyuan Zhenren of Kongtong Mountain

The Most High Lord Lao further addressed the Heavenly Master, saying: The sins and blessings, good and evil of worldly people all fall under the governance of celestial offices. To repent of sins and dispel calamities, nothing surpasses cultivation and reverence. On one’s original destiny’s birthday, at the life-mandate’s mid-cycle, at the Horse of the Year, or during the Three Disasters and Nine Calamities, one may safeguard the present and ensure the well-being of one’s kin.

Originally, Heaven and Earth bore no form, and the Dao lay hidden in primordial chaos. Before the sun and moon took shape, qi resided within the Great Simplicity. When one qi sufficed, the Yellow Center governed; when the Great Simplicity dispersed, the myriad things began to arise. The Three Powers spread transformation among the host of spirits; the Six Movements breathed through the bellows. Cold and heat shifted in alternation; the pitch-pipes harmonized in resonance. Above, the radiance of sun and moon scattered, arraying the stars; below, the clear and turbid sediments congealed, forming hills and mountains. All things were born and nurtured; all beings flourished and multiplied. Yet when humans plunder the myriad things to attain peace, things deplete humans to attain the Dao. Spring’s luxuriance yields to autumn’s decline; there is birth, and thus there is death. If one remains formless and imageless, there is no death, nor any end.

The multitude’s eyelashes are not distant from their eyes, yet they fail to see clearly. The Great Dao lies solely within the heart—how could one cultivate it without recognition? Cloud-palace and Brahma-towers, jewel gardens and soaring forests—through form one discerns the formless; by relying on conditioned causes, one knows the unconditioned. Through action one attains non-action; through form one achieves formlessness. The numinous terrace, undimmed, reflects the Dao’s clarity; dust accumulates, obscuring the spirit’s radiance. When the numinous wanes and essence scatters, the body sickens and perishes. The three hun drift into the vast, empty paths of the yin realm—oh, how boundless! The hundred joints and bodily frame lie scattered upon the desolate mounds—how desolate! Though one may rival the wealth of a kingdom, what glory remains today? Though one may bear the empty title of six seals, what benefit does it bring in the end?

The world’s deluded cling to desire, losing their original destiny; they indulge in greed, exhausting their Horses of the Year. Their eyes follow peach-red and willow-green, unaware of the source of emptiness and form; their minds chase butterflies and blossoms, unable to distinguish the divisions of causes and conditions. In the vast expanse of the sea, within the swirling vortex, how long will they drift? In the deep recesses of mountains, within the cloud-caves of stone, when will their frantic scurrying cease?

Yet worldly people abhor dampness and dwell below; they fear death and cling to life. They do not know that life is the root of death, and transgression the head of misfortune. One ought to fear dampness and dwell on high; cling to life yet transcend death; dread misfortune and guard against transgression; prevent calamity and refrain from wrongdoing. Naturally, one becomes a carefree immortal of the earthly realm.

Moreover, when sentient beings commit wrongs and violate prohibitions, their transgressions accumulate—what method can absolve them? What means can avert them? It lies in repenting past wrongs, forever severing future errors, and wholeheartedly contemplating the Great Mystery. Reverently and diligently honoring the mid-cycle of one’s own life-mandate and the Horse of the Year, one may shed the Three Disasters and Nine Calamities, safeguarding the present and ensuring the well-being of one’s kin.

What is the life-mandate’s mid-cycle, the Horse of the Year?
The *yuan* is the beginning; the *chen* is the true image; the *yi* is the dwelling-valley; the *ma* is the stubborn beast. To invoke blessings, one must pray and supplicate, seeking the original beginning, aligning with the Great Dao, harmonizing with Heaven and Earth, moving with the sun and moon, equaling the mountains, penetrating the profound and attaining the mysterious—non-action without hindrance. This *yuanchen* repents of transgressions and turns toward virtue, thereby dispelling calamities and transcending misfortune.

If one can bind the mind-monkey within the dwelling-valley of the self, restraining the will-horse, naturally the myriad disasters will not encroach, and the host of demons will bow in submission. Then one attains carefree wandering through the Three Realms, realizing the Mystery of Mysteries.

Hark!
Only when the self’s Horse of the Year is captured and subdued
May the original destiny shed the Nine Calamities.

A Hymn says:
Strike not the original spirit upon the Five Aggregates’ mountain,
For within it, illusory affairs abound in difficulty.
Deluded clouds often cling to the numinous terrace’s companion;
Love’s waves surge repeatedly within the cinnabar palace.
The Nine Calamities gradually arise as the monkey and horse flourish;
The Three Disasters turn and stir as ghosts and demons grow stubborn.
Who knows the true message revealed in illumination?
Wind and moon, serene and untouched, remain undisturbed.

Whenever superior practitioners uphold this true scripture on their original destiny’s birthday, they externally subdue demonic spirits and internally pacify their true nature. Their merit extends to the water and land realms; their goodness reaches both the living and the deceased. Through repentance and reverence, they gradually ascend to wondrous fruition, reestablish mysterious merit, and realize the Dao of Emptiness. Thus they attain sagely wisdom and perfect penetration, becoming unfathomable in concealment or manifestation, moving freely between being and non-being, wandering carefree among the clouds, ascending through the Golden Gate to unite with the sages. Their bodies transcend the Three Realms, forever freed from the wheel of rebirth, their lifespan boundless, their joy and ease self-attained.

Moreover, the distinctions between good and evil all arise from one’s actions; the two paths of fortune and misfortune truly stem from one’s conduct. Generally, when illusory demons run rampant, transgressions inevitably accumulate; when the karma of the heart is extinguished, sins also perish. Though one knows that good and evil, fortune and misfortune follow like shadows after form, they cannot be escaped.

Yet the common worldly multitudes do not know what is most intimate or what is greatest. Though they know only the Dao is greatest and only destiny most intimate—now that they recognize the Dao’s greatness and destiny’s intimacy, how should they seek it? How should they protect it? One must know that the hub arises from the wheel, and the net from its cords. With a single mind embracing rectitude, the myriad dharmas remain free from deviation. If one cannot respect what is intimate, how can one respect what is distant? If one cannot delight in what is internal, how can one delight in what is external? Thus, respecting the intimate naturally extends to the distant; delighting in the internal naturally radiates outward. Therefore, one may rectify the self, and all things will naturally follow without command.

What is intimate cannot be disrespected; what is external cannot be delighted in without first delighting within. Thus, reverence for the intimate ensures goodness toward the distant; inner joy naturally extends outward. Therefore, one may rectify the self, and all things will naturally follow without coercion.

d.

At this time, the Heavenly Master received this scripture, overflowing with joy.

The Heavenly Master is one who upholds the Dao and assists rectitude—thus called the Teacher of Heaven. Those who stray from the true and pursue the perverse are called ghosts of the earth. Therefore, those who awaken to the Great Dao of truth may truly be said to have encountered the supreme Dharma-bridge.

Hark!
One spirit upholds rectitude, free of deceit;
The Three Realms’ carefree wandering all lie within.

chunks.original_text: ○大众何如龙吟虎啸，升沉於丹鼎之中，鬼哭神号，奔窜於黄宫之外，可得证虚无之道，寿量无期，快乐自在，逍遥三界，升入金门，与圣合真矣。 咄！ 身到曲溪烟月岸，楚峰山色转分明。 颂曰： 玉虚台畔旧圆融，无碍无为万古同。 只为情迷生灭内，拘摩真觉去来中。 皆因执有还着有，纵得依空又落空。 空有可於方寸鉴，自然展转显神通。 凡有男女於本命生辰及诸斋日，清净身心，焚香持此真文，自认北极本命所属星君，随心祷祝，善无不应，灾罪消除，致感万圣千真，俱来卫护。 此文所在之处，千真敬礼，万圣护持，魔鬼潜消，精灵伏匿，世有灾殃，悉皆消灭。 且夫大道难称，玄功罔测，霈洪恩则敷於万物，布妙化则徧於八纮，有品咸亨，无物不载，然而道无不载，广施有用之恩，物遂生成，大启无为之化。 又曰：有用之空非有用，无为即色岂无为，用为要识其中理，方脱轮回兴叹悲，而知天地盖载其恩弥焉，日月照烛其恩亦然，大道化身，其孰固怜，不知身之以国，命之以君，灵之以本，气之以臣，纵妄想而迷五色，随贪爱而滞六尘。 须知君爱敬国之昌，灵气冲和身不亡，臣子忠君君爱臣，家邦从此转兴荣，蛮夷纵有多凶勇，自是无由敢战征，大底以和成晏，以正摄邪，一念顿息，万缘俱忘，若起一念之因，应受三涂之报，则有过去未来见在，舍身报身受身，迷不知涉於深渊，贪不知步於峻岭，兀兀如痴，昏昏若梦，起无明业火，毁焚楼阁之严缺，有漏迷津，散荡真元之理，是以众生斯之广矣。 凡有男女於本命生辰及诸齐日，清净身心，焚真实香，持念真文，自认北极所属星君，随心祷祝，善无不应，灾罪消除，鬼魔伏匿，愿我含生同离业果者矣。 咄！ 七真拔苦寻无地，一念忘时别有天。
chunks.translated_text:
○ O assembly! Like dragons roaring and tigers howling, ascending and descending within the cinnabar crucible; like ghosts wailing and spirits shrieking, fleeing in terror beyond the Yellow Court—thus may one attain the Dao of emptiness and formlessness, with boundless longevity, joyous freedom, and carefree wandering through the Three Realms. Ascend through the Golden Gate to unite with the sages and merge with the True.

Hark! The body arrives at the misty moonlit banks of Qu Brook, where the hues of Mount Chu’s peaks grow ever clearer.

*Verse:*
By the Jade Void Terrace, primal unity once reigned,
Unobstructed, uncontrived—eternally the same.
Yet deluded by passions within birth and death,
Bound to true awakening’s comings and goings.
All cling to being, only to grasp at being,
Though leaning on emptiness, they still fall into void.
When emptiness and being are mirrored in the square inch of the heart,
Naturally, the divine powers unfold in endless display.

Whenever men or women, on their life-destiny birthdays or during various fast days, purify body and mind, burn incense, and hold this true scripture, recognizing the Star Lord of their life-destiny at the Northern Culmen and praying with sincerity, no good shall go unanswered. Disasters and transgressions will dissolve, and ten thousand sages and thousand perfected ones will all come to guard and protect. Wherever this scripture resides, a thousand perfected pay reverence, ten thousand sages offer protection. Demons and ghosts vanish in silence, spirits and sprites hide in submission. All worldly calamities and misfortunes shall be utterly dispelled.

Moreover, the Great Dao is hard to name; its mysterious workings are unfathomable. Its vast grace spreads over the ten thousand things; its wondrous transformations pervade the eight directions. All ranks partake in its bounty; no being is left unsupported. Yet the Dao bears all without exception, bestowing the grace of utility; things thus come to life and flourish, unfolding the transformation of non-doing.

It is also said:
The emptiness of utility is not utility;
Non-doing as form—how could it be non-doing?
To grasp the principle within use and non-use
Is to escape the wheel of rebirth and end sighs of sorrow.
Know then that heaven and earth cover and bear with boundless grace;
Sun and moon illumine with equal grace.
The Dao’s transformed bodies—who would not cherish them?
Yet men know not that the body is the state,
That life is the sovereign,
That the spirit is the root,
That qi is the minister.
Lost in delusion, they are bewildered by the five colors;
Following craving, they are ensnared by the six dusts.

One must know:
When the sovereign loves and respects the state, it prospers;
When spirit and qi harmonize and surge, the body does not perish.
When ministers are loyal to the sovereign and the sovereign loves the ministers,
The household and nation from this turn to flourishing.
Though barbarians may be fierce and bold,
None dare wage war.
In general, harmony brings peace;
Rectitude subdues evil.
With a single thought stilled, the ten thousand conditions are forgotten.
If a single thought of causation arises,
One incurs the retribution of the Three Wretched Realms—
Past, future, and present;
Abandoning the body, repaying the body, receiving the body.
Deluded, one knows not the crossing of the abyss;
Greedy, one knows not the climbing of the steep ridge.
Stolid as if dumb, dazed as if dreaming,
Kindling the fire of ignorance,
Burning and destroying the splendor of the jeweled tower.
Leaking through the ford of delusion,
Scattering and dissipating the principle of true origin.
Thus are the multitudes of beings vast indeed.

Whenever men or women, on their life-destiny birthdays or during various fast days, purify body and mind, burn true incense, hold and recite this true scripture, recognizing the Star Lord of their life-destiny at the Northern Culmen and praying with sincerity, no good shall go unanswered. Disasters and transgressions will dissolve; ghosts and demons will hide in submission. May all sentient beings together escape the fruits of karmic action!

Hark! The Seven Perfected seek in vain for a place to relieve suffering—
When a single thought is forgotten, another heaven appears.

chunks.original_text: 颂曰： 万迭云山耸翠华，分明归路本无差。 争知只恁他乡好，不顾终非自己家。 去执乃为真忏悔，忘贪便是大丹砂。 降心得入幽微径，笑看溪风送落花。 是名《北斗本命延生经诀》，乃修真之径路，得道逍遥皆因此经，证圣成真皆因此经，出离生死皆因此经，保护男女皆因此经，保命延年皆得自在，永为身宝，福寿可称，保而敬之，非人勿示。 凡修道者，皆凭於保真练性之理也，乃知昧性者祸有多焉，悟真者福无少矣。 善恶施为，皆惟然於心也，祸福可鉴，皆惟然於智也。 盖凡夫在世，动念施为，行藏举止，祸福善恶，互相交错其间，分别者在乎智也，故以有善即进而从之，遇不善当退而戒之，退不善可立於功，戒为非勿失於德，可见於玄门矣。 空言退恶，不立其实功，谩说进善，弗行其实德，希夷之门，性相之理，何由达於此也。 乃以圣人垂经，譬如日月之光辉，能破黑暗，视现万物，明照诸方，使一切众生未知者知，未见者见，其功皆为天之德也。 我太上说此经教亦同日月，咸使几夫知登真入道之途，脱苦海轮回之路，其功皆为於圣之德也，乃以众生之性，亦与日月之同，洞照太虚，纤尘不染，飞空无碍，乃不知立功修德之理，障碍云生，烦恼业起，昧却灵明，涉於幽暗，贪呆#1不顾前坑之险，逐乐宁思后患之忧。 ○大众争如立功修德，其福不可称量，可济度苦魂，可永延遐算，出离生死，得道逍遥，即可证圣成真，上登三清之境矣。 咄！ 延生经诀修真路，体用皆因此一经。 颂曰： 玉壶壶内隐玄玄，欲识须当缚耍猿。 功行切宜都总备，圣真方得两皆全。 劫终不坏飞仙岛，物外犹存岂梵园。 悟到从来幽妙理，玄微极处只无言。 老君说经将毕，龙鹅天仙来迎，还於玉京。 是时天师受得妙法，而作是言，誓愿流行，以传善士，若有男女受持读诵，我当与十戒仙官所在拥护。 原夫天无私，而劝於善也，斯有道，则福无形也，人惑欲，而从其用也，斯有数，则福臻中也。 若以所得其中，则福祉之来也不可御，又奚虑其衅极也，若人所以失其中，则衅极之至也不可逃，又奚望其福祉也。 盖以善恶因由，如行车之转辐，如谷声之应逐，还报然而何以免之？ 君不见芳英满槛，难逃九月之霜，金玉盈堂，怎免百年之限，人身幻体，终於浮世岂长存，罪戾增崇，定是冥途萦永久，何如开神光射破八门关，扫氛气高升三界府。 奈何众生情迷诸漏，性积多愆，於浓浓浪里走无停，向霭霭云中迷不省，可叹三尸六鬼得胜喜容容，却叹四大百神势亏愁惨惨，云宫仙府去无门，旷野荒址应有分，将玄真浩散逐悲风，把灵魄飘悠涉鬼路，平生冤业见前来，空悔问君何去住。 故太上曰：上德不德，下德执德，执着之者，不名道德。 夫执着邪见，遇启正观，可敌群魔，握权天地，指勑万神，役袪三界之枢机也。 且以嚣尘广厚，迷障昂高，未能飞步於青云，何引凡躯於碧落，如何向五苦八难之中，到三岛十洲之外，但於方寸之间馘邪魔，奔远於寰区之外，晏忠良弼辅於朝幄之中，自然神升超世，道合自然而然，出入往来，无萦无碍，自在逍遥矣。 是乃太上垂济物度迷之法，普徧万方，周流三界，於是令天师传授众生，咸离苦业，俱入道真，持授归依，通玄究妙，洞观无碍，超入法门，自得十大仙官，翊卫修真抱一之身矣。

Hymn says:
Ten thousand layered cloud-mountains rise in emerald splendor,
The homeward path is clear—how could it ever err?
Yet who knows this foreign land is fair?
None heed that in the end it is not their true home.

To relinquish attachment is true repentance,
To forget greed is the great cinnabar elixir.
Subduing the heart, one enters the subtle path—
Smiling to see the creek-wind bear fallen blossoms.

This is called *The Northern Culmen Life-Prolonging Scripture’s Key*,
The very path of cultivating truth.
All who attain the Dao and roam freely do so through this scripture,
All who verify sageliness and achieve perfection do so through this scripture,
All who escape birth and death do so through this scripture,
All who protect men and women do so through this scripture.
To preserve life and extend years is to gain mastery—
Forever a treasure for the body,
Where fortune and longevity may be proclaimed.
Guard and revere it;
Show it not to the unworthy.

All who cultivate the Dao rely upon the principle of preserving truth and refining nature.
Thus, those who obscure their nature bring upon themselves manifold misfortunes,
While those who awaken to truth know boundless blessings.
Good and evil actions arise solely from the heart;
Fortune and misfortune are discerned solely through wisdom.
For the common person in the world,
Every thought, every deed, every movement and repose,
Fortune and misfortune, good and evil,
Intermingle and intertwine.
Discernment lies in wisdom:
When encountering good, advance and follow it;
When meeting evil, retreat and guard against it.
To retreat from evil is to establish merit;
To guard against wrongdoing is to preserve virtue.
Thus may one enter the Mystery Gate.

Empty words of forsaking evil, without establishing true merit,
Idle talk of advancing good, without practicing true virtue—
How can one attain the Gate of the Invisible and Inaudible,
Or comprehend the principle of nature and appearance?

The sages bequeathed scriptures like the radiance of sun and moon,
Dispelling darkness, revealing all things,
Illuminating every direction,
Enabling all beings to know what they knew not,
To see what they had not seen.
Such is the virtue of Heaven.

Our Most High expounded this scripture and teaching, like sun and moon,
Enabling all to know the path of ascending to truth and entering the Dao,
The way to escape the wheel of suffering and rebirth.
Such is the virtue of the sages.

The nature of all beings is akin to sun and moon,
Pervading the great void, unstained by the tiniest dust,
Soaring through empty space without hindrance.
Yet they know not the principle of establishing merit and cultivating virtue.
Obstructions arise like clouds,
Afflictions and karma stir,
Their luminous clarity is obscured,
And they wander into darkness.
Greed-blinded, they heed not the peril of the pit ahead;
Pursuing pleasure, they forget the sorrows of future calamity.

O assembly! How much better to establish merit and cultivate virtue,
Whose blessings are beyond measure!
They can deliver suffering souls,
Eternally prolong destiny,
Escape birth and death,
Attain the Dao and roam freely,
Verify sageliness and achieve perfection,
Ascend to the Three Clarities’ realm!

Hark!
The *Life-Prolonging Scripture’s Key* is the path of cultivating truth—
Essence and function both derive from this one scripture.

Hymn says:
Within the jade pot lies the profoundest mystery;
To know it, one must first bind the restless monkey-mind.
Diligently perfect merit and conduct in full—
Only then may sageliness and truth both be complete.
At the kalpa’s end, the flying immortal isle remains unharmed;
Beyond the world, how could it be confined to a Brahma-garden?
When one awakens to the ever-subtle principle,
At the ultimate depth of the mysterious, there are no words.

As the Elder Lord concluded his discourse,
Dragon-phoenixes and celestial immortals came to welcome him,
Returning to Jade Capital.
Then the Heavenly Master, having received the wondrous Dharma, declared:
“I vow to propagate it widely,
To transmit it to the virtuous.
If any man or woman receives, upholds, reads, or recites it,
I and the ten precept-enforcing immortal officials shall protect them wherever they may be.”

For Heaven is impartial,
And urges all toward goodness.
Where the Dao is present, blessings arise unseen;
When people are deluded by desire and follow its dictates,
Fortune aligns with destiny.
If one attains the mean,
Blessings come unbidden—
What need to fear calamity’s extremity?
If one loses the mean,
Calamity’s extremity arrives inescapably—
What hope then for blessings?

Good and evil causes are like a turning wheel’s spokes,
Like an echo following a sound—
How can one avoid their retribution?

Have you not seen:
Fragrant blossoms filling the railing cannot escape the frost of the ninth month;
Gold and jade filling the hall cannot avoid the hundred-year limit.
The human body is an illusory form—
How can it endure forever in the floating world?
As transgressions accumulate,
One is surely bound to the underworld’s eternal coils.
How much better to open the divine radiance,
Shattering the eight gates’ barriers,
Sweeping away the miasmic qi,
Ascending to the Three Realms’ palace!

Alas! Sentient beings, deluded by the manifold leaks,
Their natures burdened with manifold faults,
Rush ceaselessly through the surging waves,
Wander lost in the misty clouds, never awakening.
The Three Corpses and Six Ghosts rejoice in triumph,
While the Four Great Elements and hundred spirits grieve in sorrow.
The cloud-palace and immortal mansion are barred to them;
The desolate wilds must be their destined abode.
Their primordial truth scattered by the mournful wind,
Their spirit-souls adrift on the ghostly path,
Lifelong karmic debts appear before them—
In vain they repent, asking: “Where shall we go?”

Thus the Most High said:
“The highest virtue does not act as virtue;
The lesser virtue clings to virtue.
Those who cling are not called virtuous.”

Clinging to perverse views,
When one encounters right vision,
Can repel all demons,
Grasp the authority of Heaven and Earth,
Command the myriad spirits,
And wield the pivot of the Three Realms.

Yet the clamor of the dusty world is vast,
The delusions and obstructions towering—
How can one soar upon the azure clouds,
Or guide the mortal frame to the azure vault?
How can one, amid the five sufferings and eight difficulties,
Reach beyond the three isles and ten continents?
But within the square inch of the heart,
One may slay demons and banish them beyond the world’s bounds,
Serve loyal ministers in the imperial court,
Naturally ascending as a transcendent,
The Dao in harmony with spontaneity.
Coming and going, unbound and unhindered,
One roams freely and at ease.

This is the Most High’s method of aiding beings and delivering the deluded,
Pervading all directions,
Circulating through the Three Realms.
Thus he commanded the Heavenly Master to transmit it to all beings,
That all may escape suffering and karma,
Together enter the truth of the Dao.
Upholding and receiving it,
One penetrates the mysterious and fathoms the wondrous,
Gains unobstructed insight,
Transcends and enters the Dharma-gate,
And naturally attains the protection of the ten great immortal officials,
Guarding the body of the cultivator who embraces the One.

chunks.original_text: 咄！ 一心摧斩诸魔鬼，众苦翻为十善神。 颂曰： 众流分派育群生，雪月辉光雨霁晴。 千浦浪浑千月暗，一溪波静一轮明。 元同真处异何异，只为迷来成不成。 却笑落花飞片片，野禽由自弄多情。 於是再拜老君，而说赞曰： 家有《北斗经》本命降真灵。 颂曰： 琼文奥旨甚叮咛，为恐众生落夜扃。 故说太玄玄妙理，指开顽识识空形。 祥风灌透黄华馆，慧月光辉丹界亭。 运取圣功非内外，神明应是降直灵#2。 家有《北斗经》，宅舍得安宁。 颂曰： 谁能顿解悟真经，遣去凡情护我形。
chunks.translated_text:
Hark! With single-minded resolve, smite and sever all demonic spirits,
Transforming the host of sufferings into the ten spirits of goodness.

*Ode:*
The myriad streams branch forth to nurture all beings,
As snow and moon gleam bright, rain clears to fair skies.
A thousand inlets churn with waves, a thousand moons grow dim,
Yet one stream’s waves stilled, a single orb shines clear.
In origin, the true state is the same—what difference lies between them?
Only delusion turns what is into what is not.
Then laugh at the falling blossoms, petals drifting,
While wild birds freely indulge their many passions.

Thereupon, bowing again to the Venerable Lord, he spoke this eulogy:

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper* commands the descent of true numinosity.

*Ode:*
The jade-text’s profound purport is most earnest,
Lest sentient beings fall into the night’s barred gate.
Thus the Supreme Mystery’s wondrous principle is expounded,
Pointing to open the stubborn mind, discerning form as emptiness.
Auspicious winds bathe the Yellow Blossom Palace,
The moon of wisdom illumines the Crimson Realm Pavilion.
Invoking sacred merit, neither within nor without,
The divine luminaries surely descend in direct response.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
The household and dwelling secure peace and tranquility.

*Ode:*
Who can suddenly comprehend and awaken to the true scripture,
Dispelling mundane attachments to guard this form?

chunks.original_text: 炼性保神精养血，固根离爱气和灵。 泥丸运得开明月，液海应擒照鉴星。 六识若降无患恶，自然宅合得安宁。 家有《北斗经》，父母保长生。 颂曰： 勤修妙相体圆明，方寸休教染垢尘。 默默施为仙行业，绵绵进用道功程。 十华定举标金格，五老须从注玉名。 皆自一身持戒善，庆敷九祖保长茔。 家有《北斗经》，诸厌化为尘。 颂曰： 但能常静暨常清，天地咸宁万法明。 神谷长存开玉蕊，刀圭乃得产金晶。 宝壶腾瑞龙蛇戏，寿鼎飞光鬼魅惊。 若取圣功频煅炼，自然诸厌化为尘。 家有《北斗经》，万邪自归正。 颂曰： 心猿缚住入玄帏，妙相庄严自此威。 斡转玄关塞地穴，驱回妙范夺天机。 慧锋诛斩妖魔尽，法印宣威魍魉稀。 荡荡满怀风与月，万邪稽首自归依。 家有《北斗经》，营业得称情。 颂曰： 方寸修持坦坦平，尘缘都没半毫萦。
chunks.translated_text:
Cultivating nature to preserve the spirit, refining essence to nourish the blood,
Firming the root by forsaking desire, harmonizing qi and numinosity.
The Mud-Pill Palace set in motion reveals the bright moon,
The Sea of Fluids responds by capturing the mirrored stars.
Should the six senses be subdued, no ills or evils arise,
Naturally the dwelling aligns and secures peace.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
Parents are preserved in long life.

*Ode:*
Diligently cultivate the wondrous form, the body luminously complete,
Let not the square inch of the heart be stained by dust or grime.
Silently enact the immortal’s deeds,
Ceaselessly advance the workings of the Dao’s merit.
The Ten Flowers surely rise, marking the golden standard,
The Five Elders must inscribe the jade names.
All stems from the body’s observance of precepts and goodness,
Joyfully extending to nine generations, preserving long repose.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
All aversions dissolve into dust.

*Ode:*
Simply abide in constant stillness and constant purity,
Heaven and earth attain tranquility, the ten thousand dharmas become clear.
The Spirit Valley endures, unfolding jade blossoms,
The elixir spoon yields golden crystals.
The treasure vase emits auspiciousness, dragons and serpents play,
The cauldron of longevity radiates light, startling ghosts and demons.
Should one seize the sacred merit and refine it ceaselessly,
Naturally all aversions dissolve into dust.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
The myriad evils spontaneously return to rectitude.

*Ode:*
The mind-ape bound, entering the mysterious curtain,
The wondrous form adorned, from this its majesty arises.
Turning the Mysterious Pass, sealing the earth’s cavern,
Driving back the wondrous norm, seizing heaven’s mechanism.
The blade of wisdom slays all demons and devils,
The Dharma-seal proclaims might, specters grow scarce.
Vast and boundless, the heart filled with wind and moon,
The myriad evils bow their heads, returning to submission.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
One’s livelihood attains contentment.

*Ode:*
The square inch of the heart cultivated, level and smooth,
Worldly entanglements wholly vanish, not a thread clings.

chunks.original_text: 三尸计摄归玄理，六贼机图灭怪狞。 现出曲汉山月朗，透开春色谷风清。 不知这个生涯事，谁肯经营得称情。 家有《北斗经》，阖门自康健。 颂曰： 不在驱驱度远关，道迷云外得应难。 神光只照无为路，法眼休观有碍山。 朱合玉楼真造化，清风明月乐翛间。 幽庵活计人能会，从却庵疏主亦安。 家有《北斗经》，子孙保荣盛。 颂曰： 空洞灵台瑞霭清，汪洋和气徧区纮。 云峦硌硌神风冷，烟舍萧萧皓月明。 野史笛吹无事韵，牧童歌唱太平声。 自从认得山家乐，姹女婴儿展转荣。 家有《北斗经》，五路自通达。 颂曰： 纲纪经纶事业兴，忠心匡国辅高明。 未容谗佞食君禄，常许功勋作帝卿。 宇宙既能施正化，江山应是肃然清。 同瞻圣主巍巍德，载路通亨贺太平。 家有《北斗经》，众恶永消灭。 颂曰： 谁肯调驯猿马情，免教奔窜误前程。 对他桃李舒晴日，收拾生涯隐故京。 好是雨余山色净，只愁云暗月华明。 若能但把俗情灭，众恶何由得自生。 家有《北斗经》，六畜保兴生。 颂曰： 识得浮华事可惊，便宜回首舍凡情。 任从目下般般冗，不运心时洒洒清。 活计勿亏应有盛，功名休怠不无成。 也知别更求何利，六畜宁来主自荣。 家有《北斗经》，疾病得痊瘥。 颂曰： 一念休教业所牵，百关调畅保延年。 勿令真气时时损，常使灵源日日添。 龙虎不能停战斗，坎离岂运自团圆。 不须草木夺神理，定是灾除乐泰然。 家有《北斗经》，财物不虚耗。 颂曰： 这颗玄珠无价酬，众生皆有不能收。 本如明月澄江水，元若清风动素秋。 且好牢藏先准备，莫教散失后成忧。 金门玉户宜常闭，免使狂猿起意偷。 家有《北斗经》，横事永不起。 颂曰： 回光返照灭尘心，莫负玄门振法音。 只在目前分造化，休迷云外别搜寻。 寒岩月朗山猿唳，谷树花芳野鸟吟。 若肯的然行此道，非灾何为得能侵。 家有《北斗经》，长保亨利贞。 颂曰： 莫将无漏等闲轻，好慕真空进妙程。 常托赤松为取用，每从苍昊变亏盈。 分开羃羃阴云翳，现出辉辉皓月明。 打当尘嚣无半点，忻哉长保利亨贞。 老君曰：善哉善哉，汝可宣扬正教，福利无边，普及众生，永沾胜善。 解曰：碧天秋霁夜无云，月影辉辉落水滨。 争奈怒风来太恶，沸波摇散玉华轮。
chunks.translated_text:
The Three Corpses’ schemes are captured by the mysterious principle,
The Six Thieves’ devices dissolve, their monstrous ferocity vanishes.
The winding Milky Way emerges, its moon bright,
The spring hues of the valley open, its winds pure and clear.
Who would know this as the livelihood of the Way,
Or willingly cultivate it to attain contentment?

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
The whole household naturally enjoys health.

*Ode:*
No need to rush through distant passes,
For those lost beyond the clouds, the Dao is hard to find.
The divine radiance illumines only the path of non-action,
The Dharma-eye ceases to gaze upon obstructing mountains.
The vermilion gates and jade towers are true creation,
In the joy of clear wind and bright moon, one roams free.
If one grasps the livelihood of the secluded hermitage,
Even the hermit’s sparse host finds peace.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
Descendants preserve prosperity and glory.

*Ode:*
The empty, numinous terrace, its auspicious mists pure,
A boundless harmony pervades the vast expanse.
Cloud-capped peaks stand cold in the divine wind,
Smoke-wreathed cottages gleam under the bright moon.
The rustic flute plays an idle, carefree tune,
The shepherd boy sings the voice of Great Peace.
Since recognizing the joy of the mountain dweller,
The alchemical maiden and infant flourish in turn.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
The five paths naturally open and connect.

*Ode:*
With governance and discipline, undertakings prosper,
Loyal hearts aid the state and assist the wise.
Never allow slanderers to consume the ruler’s bounty,
Ever permit meritorious deeds to serve as the emperor’s ministers.
Since the cosmos can enact true transformation,
The rivers and mountains should be solemn and clear.
Together we behold the august virtue of the sagely lord,
Every road unobstructed, celebrating Great Peace.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
All evils are forever extinguished.

*Ode:*
Who would tame the unruly mind-ape and horse,
To prevent their reckless flight from ruining the journey ahead?
Facing peach and plum blossoms in the sunlit day,
One gathers life’s livelihood, retiring to the old capital.
How fine the mountain’s clarity after the rain,
Yet one frets when clouds darken the moon’s brilliance.
If only one could extinguish worldly passions,
How could evils ever arise of their own accord?

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
The six livestock thrive and multiply.

*Ode:*
Recognizing the alarm in fleeting vanities,
One should promptly turn away and abandon mundane attachments.
Though present matters may seem endlessly trivial,
When the mind is not set in motion, all is naturally pure.
Livelihood will not lack abundance if not neglected,
Achievements will surely come if not abandoned.
What other profit could one seek,
When the six livestock prosper and the master flourishes?

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
Illnesses find healing and recovery.

*Ode:*
Let not a single thought be bound by karmic ties,
With all passages harmonized, life is preserved and prolonged.
Do not allow true qi to be constantly depleted,
But let the numinous source be daily replenished.
Dragon and tiger cannot cease their strife,
Kan and Li do not spontaneously unite.
No need for herbs to usurp the spirit’s principle—
Disasters will surely vanish, and joy will reign.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
Wealth and possessions are not wasted.

*Ode:*
This mysterious pearl is beyond price,
Yet all beings possess it and cannot retain it.
It is like the bright moon mirrored in the river’s waters,
Or the pure wind stirring the white autumn.
It is best to secure it firmly in advance,
Lest it scatter and become a later sorrow.
The golden gate and jade door should always be shut,
To prevent the wild ape from conceiving thieving thoughts.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
Misfortunes never arise.

*Ode:*
Turning the light inward to extinguish the dust-heart,
Do not fail the mysterious gate’s resounding Dharma-voice.
Creation and transformation lie before your eyes,
Do not wander beyond the clouds in vain search.
The cold cliff’s moon shines bright, the mountain ape cries,
The valley’s trees bloom fragrant, the wild birds sing.
If one truly practices this Dao,
What disaster could ever intrude?

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
Ever preserve smoothness, benefit, and integrity.

*Ode:*
Do not treat the untainted as trivial,
But aspire to true emptiness and advance on the wondrous path.
Often rely on Red Pine for sustenance,
Ever follow the Azure Vault in its waxing and waning.
Parting the dense veil of yin clouds,
The radiant bright moon emerges in splendor.
Dispelling the dust’s clamor without a trace,
Joyfully one ever preserves smoothness, benefit, and integrity.

The Lord Lao said: Excellent, excellent! You may propagate the true teaching, bringing boundless blessings and benefits to all beings, that they may forever partake in supreme goodness.

*Explanation:*
The autumn sky clears at dusk, clouds absent,
The moon’s radiance shines bright upon the waterside.
Yet how fierce the raging wind’s sudden fury,
Churning waves scatter the jade-like orb.
chunks.overlap_context:
Driving back the wondrous norm, seizing heaven’s mechanism.
The blade of wisdom slays all demons and devils,
The Dharma-seal proclaims might, specters grow scarce.
Vast and boundless, the heart filled with wind and moon,
The myriad evils bow their heads, returning to submission.

Within the home, the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper*:
One’s livelihood attains contentment.

*Ode:*
The square inch of the heart cultivated, level and smooth,
Worldly entanglements wholly vanish, not a thread clings.

chunks.original_text: 切谓猿心颠耍，宜调伏於玉洞之间，马意劣顽，可系縻於玄山之下，野外多春草，山前足异芳，马猿还不系，逐景定奔狂，境界来时无准备，柳烟深处定迷踪，柳塘花坞春明丽，牵引时人玩景游，信步不思归去晚，急回斜日过江楼。 谓浮生幻化，那堪日月如校，荣辱虚华，更叹韶光似水，忍造愆非，魂沉寒夜，不知省悟，魄堕幽阴，切以金钟高架木不扣兮，终日无音，宝月空悬云不蔽兮，通宵自朗，譬若心不动兮性常定，外不入兮内常安，内安则万法皆明，性定则群魔自伏，何幽不烛，何化不行。 奈尔凡夫昏朦真性，纵情纵欲，转轮六道之中，何德何修，甘堕九泉之下，月馆松溪，无恋意囚牢，火宅竞钻头，只於苦海贪荣辱，辜负真元逐浪流，被诸尘漏，缘觉声闻，逐景沉迷，量因生灭，迷误不省，竞着群情，自沉苦趣失人身，何日再重登道岸。 深蒙太上重演真诠，普济众生，永沾胜善。 咄！
chunks.translated_text:
Guard against the monkey-mind’s frivolous antics—tame it within the jade grotto;
Curb the horse-intent’s stubbornness—tie it beneath the dark mountain.
Beyond the wilds, spring grasses flourish;
Before the peaks, rare fragrances abound.
Yet if horse and monkey remain untethered,
They chase the fleeting scene in reckless flight.
When the realm’s illusions arise unprepared,
Amid the deep willow mist, one’s trace is surely lost.

By willow ponds and flowered bowers, spring gleams bright,
Luring mortals to wander and gaze.
Trusting their steps, they forget the hour’s late return;
Swiftly the slanting sun passes the riverside tower.

This floating life is but illusion—how can one bear the days and months as a tally?
Glory and disgrace are empty splendor—still more, the sigh for time’s flow like water.
To endure the creation of transgressions is to let the soul sink in the cold night;
To remain unenlightened is to let the spirit fall into shadowed yin.

Consider the golden bell hung high—if the wood is unstruck, the day ends soundless;
The precious moon hangs in the void—if clouds do not veil it, the night remains radiant.
Thus, if the mind does not stir, the nature abides in constancy;
If the outer does not intrude, the inner remains at peace.
With inner peace, the ten thousand dharmas grow clear;
With nature’s constancy, the myriad demons submit of themselves.
What darkness is left unilluminated?
What transformation cannot unfold?

Alas! You common folk, dull to your true nature,
Indulge in passions and desires,
Revolving endlessly through the six paths—
What virtue, what cultivation have you?
Willingly you sink beneath the nine springs.
By moonlit pavilions and pine streams, no thought of escape from the prison;
In the burning house, you but thrust your head deeper—
Ever in the sea of suffering, craving glory and disgrace,
You betray your true origin, swept along by the waves.
Ensnared by the dust’s leaks,
Bound to the cycles of arising and ceasing as pratyeka and śrāvaka,
Chasing scenes, lost in delusion—
Measuring causes by birth and death,
Bewildered, unrepentant,
You cling to the throng’s passions,
Sinking yourselves in bitter destinies, losing the human form.
When shall you again ascend the Dao’s shore?

By the Most High’s profound grace, the true canon is once more expounded,
Universally saving all beings,
That they may forever partake in supreme goodness.

Hark!

chunks.original_text: 太上善哉真法语，众生普福利无边。 颂曰： 圆融妙相本庄严，大霈玄恩无背偏。 万物俱蒙真造化，群灵咸隐太幽玄。 龙蛇有宝非奇特，天地无恩实可怜。 识破用中无用理，剖开混沌见机权。 天师稽首礼谢，信受奉行。 注曰：道徧十方，泽沾万汇，化育含灵，混成众类，细入尘沙，大包天地，日月之纲，阴阳之纬，用之则辉，背之则昧，隐显随机，变通量器，智者乃符，非人勿示，轻则匪臻，敬之必至，故立玄门，识真辩伪，普使超升，咸辞溺坠，功就行成，神飞仙位，愿我众生，皆逢正义，慎之慎之，无二无二。 颂曰： 千经万论破痴迷，更不回头待甚时。
chunks.translated_text:
O Most High’s true and excellent Dharma words,
Universally bestowing boundless blessings upon all beings.

In verse it is proclaimed:
The wondrous, all-pervading form is inherently majestic,
The vast and mysterious grace knows no partiality.
All things partake in the true work of creation,
All spirits abide in the profound and hidden mystery.
Dragons and serpents possess treasures—yet these are not rare;
Heaven and earth show no favor—truly pitiable indeed.
Discern the principle of use within the useless,
Split open the chaos to reveal the subtle mechanism.

The Heavenly Master bows in reverence, giving thanks,
Receiving and upholding the teachings with faith.

Annotation:
The Dao pervades the ten directions,
Its blessings suffuse all things.
It nurtures and transforms all beings,
Uniting all kinds in perfect harmony.
Subtle as motes of dust,
Vast as heaven and earth,
It governs the warp of sun and moon,
The weft of yin and yang.
Embrace it, and it shines;
Turn from it, and it dims.
Hidden or manifest, it follows the moment’s need,
Adapting to each vessel’s measure.
Only the wise align with it—
It must not be shown to the unworthy.
Treat it lightly, and it will not be attained;
Revere it, and it will surely come.
Thus is the Mystery Gate established,
To discern the true and expose the false,
That all may ascend,
And none drown in the depths.
When merit is perfected and conduct complete,
The spirit soars to the immortal’s rank.
May all beings encounter the true teaching,
Take heed, take heed—
Let there be no duality, no duality.

In verse it is proclaimed:
A thousand scriptures, ten thousand treatises shatter delusion—
Why wait any longer to turn back?

chunks.original_text: 业海自今宜出浪，罪山从此好平持。 心间未及於人计，意下先除润己私。 道德两全功行备，烟霞独步乐无为。 太上玄灵北斗本命延生真经注解卷下竟 #1『贪呆』之『呆』，疑误。 #2『直灵』，疑为『真灵』之误。 后　　序 盖闻昊天皇皇，至高至邈，无梯可以倚其上，无路可以达其中。 大道默默，至幽至玄，无计可以度其元，无方可以测其理，於是以善为升天之径，以经为入道之门，善则通於云衢，经则露其隐奥，则非善乃天之无路，则非经乃道之无门。 是故立经度死，垂教开生，而况厥恩莫大乎经也，其福莫大乎善也。 夫圣人垂经，则有恩而无，凡夫奉善，则无福而有，因心以作，所由生也，若得遇玄文，空披视已，不戒不奉，匪究匪穷，何异有患求医，唯诵验而不饵於药，恐刑开律，但解科而罔戒於非，思之矣然，而览之岂可获其济也。 凡有得遇，可戒奉之，庶乎俾寒狱之冰消，使火山之焰息，可得蓬宫阆苑注籍得道之名，幽府罗酆落部拘囚之目，咸拯识灵，同登道岸，余行微性，不愧聋言，谬作叹文，标其经阕。 眉山苏轼序。
chunks.translated_text:
Let the karmic sea from this day forth be calmed of its waves,
Let the mountain of transgressions hence be leveled and held steady.
Before the mind has reckoned for others,
First remove from the heart all self-serving gain.
When virtue and power are both perfected and merit complete,
One walks alone through mist and clouds, delighting in non-action.
*Tai Shang Xuan Ling Bei Dou Ben Ming Yan Sheng Zhen Jing Zhu Jie*, Volume the Lower, concludes.

#1 The character "呆" in "贪呆" appears to be an error.
#2 "直灵" is likely a miswriting of "真灵."

**Postface**

I have heard that the vast and august Heaven is most high and most distant—
No ladder can reach its heights, no path can enter its midst.
The Great Dao is most profound and most mysterious—
No reckoning can fathom its origin, no method can plumb its principles.
Thus, goodness is made the path to ascend to Heaven,
And scriptures the gate to enter the Dao.
Goodness opens the way to the celestial thoroughfare,
Scriptures reveal their hidden mysteries.
Without goodness, Heaven has no path;
Without scriptures, the Dao has no gate.
Therefore, scriptures are established to deliver the dead,
Teachings are bequeathed to open the way to life.
Yet what grace is greater than scripture?
What blessing is greater than goodness?

The sages bestow scriptures, giving boundless grace;
Ordinary beings uphold goodness, receiving boundless fortune.
All arises from the heart—
This is the source of life.
But if one merely encounters the mysterious text,
Flips through its pages without heed or reverence,
Fails to study it deeply or exhaust its meaning,
How is this different from one afflicted who seeks a physician,
Yet only recites the prescription without taking the medicine?
Or one who, upon the law’s enactment,
Understands its statutes but does not guard against wrongdoing?
Reflect upon this—
How can mere reading bring deliverance?

All who encounter this teaching should uphold and revere it,
That the icy prisons of the cold hells may melt,
The flames of the fiery mountains be quenched.
Then may one’s name be inscribed in the registers of Penglai and Langyuan,
The ledgers of Youfu and Luofeng’s captive souls be stricken,
All awakened spirits be delivered,
And together ascend the shore of the Dao.

My conduct is meager, my nature flawed—
I am no better than the deaf and mute.
Yet I have presumptuously composed this eulogy,
Marking the close of this scripture.

A postface by Su Shi of Meishan.
